title: 108_hr1096
content: The Act is titled the "Border Infrastructure and Technology Modernization Act" and includes definitions for various terms. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as Commissioner, Maquiladora, Northern border, Southern border, and Under Secretary. During fiscal years 2004 through 2008, the Under Secretary is required to increase the number of full-time agents and support staff in the Bureau of Immigration and Customs Enforcement by at least 100 more than the previous year, and the number of full-time inspectors and support staff in the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection by at least 200 more than the previous year. The Under Secretary can waive fte limitations for Homeland Security personnel. Training is provided to agents and support staff to use new technologies and maintain proficiency levels for border protection. SEC. 4. PORT OF ENTRY INFRASTRUCTURE ASSESSMENT STUDY. The Administrator of General Services must update the Port of Entry Infrastructure Assessment Study annually by January 31 and submit it to Congress. Consultation with key officials is required, and each updated study must contain specific content. The updated study required by the Administrator of General Services must identify port of entry infrastructure and technology improvement projects to enhance border security and facilitate legitimate commerce. Projects must be prioritized based on security requirements and trade facilitation, with implementation in order of priority assigned. The Commissioner may diverge from the priority order based on significantly changed circumstances, such as immediate security needs or changes in infrastructure in Mexico or Canada, that compellingly alter the need for a project in the United States. SEC. 5. NATIONAL LAND BORDER SECURITY PLAN. The Under Secretary must prepare a National Land Border Security Plan by January 31 each year and consult with relevant agencies. The plan should include a vulnerability assessment of each port of entry on the northern or southern border. Port security coordinators may be established at these entry points. The Under Secretary prepares a National Land Border Security Plan annually, including a vulnerability assessment of ports of entry on the northern or southern border. Port security coordinators may be established to assist with the assessment and plan preparation. SEC. 6. EXPANSION OF COMMERCE SECURITY PROGRAMS. The Commissioner, in consultation with the Under Secretary, must develop a plan to expand Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism programs along the northern and southern borders within 180 days of the Act's enactment. This includes various industry partnership programs administered by the Commissioner. The Commissioner will establish a demonstration program along the southern border to implement a Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism program. Another demonstration program will focus on developing a cooperative trade security system to enhance supply chain security. SEC. 7. PORT OF ENTRY TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM. The Under Secretary will conduct a technology demonstration program to test and evaluate new port of entry technologies, refine operational concepts, and train personnel under realistic conditions. Technologies tested will enhance port operations, including inspections, communications, tracking, identification of persons and cargo, sensory devices, personal detection, decision support, and detection of weapons of mass destruction. Facilities will be developed at a selected demonstration site to provide training to law enforcement personnel responsible for border security. The Under Secretary will conduct a technology demonstration program at 3-5 sites to test new port of entry technologies and train law enforcement personnel responsible for border security. Selected facilities will have up-to-date design, sufficient space, low traffic volume, and efficient operations for the program. The technology demonstration program will be conducted at 3-5 sites to test new port of entry technologies. Selected sites must meet specific criteria, including being established within 15 years, consisting of at least 65 acres with room for expansion, and servicing an average of no more than 50,000 vehicles per month. Additionally, other agencies can utilize these sites to test technologies that enhance port operations. The technology demonstration program will test new port of entry technologies at 3-5 sites, including inspections, communications, port tracking, identification of persons and cargo, sensory devices, personal detection, decision support, and detection of weapons of mass destruction. The Under Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on activities at each demonstration site and assess the feasibility of incorporating demonstrated technology for wider use. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2008 for various sections outlined in the document. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2008 includes $30,000,000 for a demonstration project, $5,000,000 for subsection (b), and $50,000,000 for technology demonstration program activities at ports of entry. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2004 through 2008 includes $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. Funds can be used for projects related to border security agreements with Mexico and Canada.
